captions.text:
(blues music with
whistling and bass beats)
- Maybe it's just your side of the table?

- Maybe you should take your
sweatshirt off, Garrett?
- Let's just turn down the A.C.
- Better idea, let's go to the bathroom,
splash some water on our face.

- Yeah, the thermostat's
like, right there,
It's central air, so if we mess with it,
- I don't think that's how A.C. works.
Here, why don't you wear my sweatshirt,
and I'll just fiddle with it.

(laughs) I just mean
that's brisk, but sure.
- Let me, let me take a look at that,

I'm great with electronics.
- [Cold Girl] No, no, no.

- That's the same one
that I have at my house,

- I think it's complicated.
- so I can help, too.
Please, you just, you don't understand.

It's gonna be so cold.
- [Bearded Man] Let me fix it!
I wanna get in there, let me fix it!
- 65, make sure to put it on 65.

- I'm really hot!
(group urges requests at once)
- You don't know what it's like, you guys!

I already have goosebumps
all over my whole body!
They make it too cold inside!
Are you trying to kill me?
- Should I go turn it down a little more?

- My hair is growing
through my arms right now.

title: The Worst Case Scenario For A Perpetually Cold Person

comments.text: Hahaha xD this is terrible and it always happens at some point.﻿
comments.author: MissManiacTheMad

comments.text: 65 degrees Fahrenheit = 18,3 degrees Celcius, you're welcome.﻿
comments.author: MrsPunkella

comments.text:
Something is wrong with Americans. Maybe it's because they're so fat but 
I've never been in a place full of so many people that are always so hot 
and sweaty. Keeping any room or building regardless of the season in the 60 
degree range is absolutely ridiculous. Lose some weight or get your thyroid 
checked. I had a teacher back in high school that would perpetually keep 
the room 50 degrees and would still sweat like a hog and complain.﻿

comments.author: secondbatch26

comments.text:
As a kid I always wondered if this had something to do with body 
temperature. My normal body temperature is 97.7 (recall that 98.6 is 
"average"), and I wonder if people with lower body temperatures are always 
feeling hot (as I always did), while people with higher body temperatures 
are always feeling cold and our bodies are just trying to balance out inner 
and outer temperatures to some degree. That was my theory at least.

Also having a 97.7 body temperature as "your normal" sucked, because if you 
came away with a 99.8 fever for example everyone would tell you it's "not 
that bad", because the 98.6 average is assumed for everyone.﻿

comments.text:
I feel lucky... In Fahrenheit, this is me:
20- FUCKING FREEZING
20-30 A sweater, and mittens is needed
30-40 Sweater is needed
40-50 Sweater is somewhat preferable
50-70 Can wear anything perfectly fine
70-80 Shorts are somewhat preferable
80-90- Shorts are wanted
90-100 shorts are needed
100-110 endurable, but short everything
110-120 Suffering
120+ YOU HAVE TO BE FUCKING KIDDING ME﻿

comments.text:
This is literally me in my house, my school, my car. 
Mom: Turn the frickin heat down it's too hot
Me: *glares and goes to the thermestat raising it*
2 minutes after
Dad: Who turned the heat on?!
Mom: I thought she turned it down!
Me: *cries inside as I watch Dad turn the heat off*
5 minutes later
*Under 5 blankets wearing 3 sweaters and chained family to self for body 
heat*﻿

OMG this is me.... I don't know what's wrong with my body, but I only stop

This one time I was in uni with a friend and she was really hot and taking 
off her sweater while I was shiverig and putting on my scarf... and she was 
all like "are you ill or something?" And I was like nope....that's just how 
I am...

....then she went to open the window and I yelled "DENIED! SIT DOWN!"﻿
